title: sans serif complement to Chaparral?
content:
Hi,

I'm using [Chaparral Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20141018045518/http:/www.linotype.com/44246/chaparralproregular-font.html) as copy in a book I am writing about school yearbooks.

Because the book also has magazine style sections, I'm trying to find sans serifs which work well with Chaparral.

I was thinking of using [Expressway](http://web.archive.org/web/20141018045518/http:/www.typodermic.com/31.html) by Ray Larabie, but I always get the feeling they clash a little.

-\> Any suggestions on what sans work well with Chaparral?

The overall look I am trying to achieve is 'fresh', 'reservedly exciting', and 'confident'.

Thanks for your drips of knowledge.
author: noftus

comments.content: I'm using Chaparral with Trade Gothic for a hip financial magazine.

I'm no professional and my palette is limited but I think Neutraface works well with Chaparral. The x-height and weights match up well. I also like Neutraface display drafting as a titling font with Chaparral.
The informal shapes of Chaparral will probably play real nice with Auto Sans (Underware).

You might get some inspitation from Tom's blog entry on the font...

[http://blogs.adobe.com/typblography/2005/11/most\_overlooked\_1.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20141018045518/http:/blogs.adobe.com/typblography/2005/11/most_overlooked_1.html "http://blogs.adobe.com/typblography/2005/11/most\_overlooked\_1.html")

...or you might not.

Thanks guys,

I ended up going with Cronos, and Trade Gothic for the more striking sections.
Or better usethe original Today Sans from Scanngraphics.
